docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush tonight proposed doubling the amount of money his administration spends on education in Africa, to $200 million over the next five years. Mr. Bush also said he intended to visit Africa next year, which would be his first trip to the continent.

headline.main: Bush Proposes Doubling U.S. Support for Education in Africa

docs.abstract: Pres Bush proposes doubling amount of money his administration spends on education in Africa, to $200 million over next five years; says he intends to visit Africa next year; makes announcement prior to summit meeting of industrial nations in Canada, at which Africa's development is to be discussed; $200 million would train teachers and pay for 4.5 million textbooks and scholarships for girls; Bush, at Washington dinner in memory of Rev Leon H Sullivan, also repeats commitment to spend $500 million to prevent pregnant women from passing on AIDS virus to babies (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush tonight proposed doubling the amount of money his administration spends on education in Africa, to $200 million over the next five years.    Mr. Bush also said he intended to visit Africa next year, which would be his first trip to the...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You note (editorial, June 20) that 55 Palestinian intellectuals took out an advertisement expressing their belief that suicide bombings ''do not achieve progress toward achieving our . . . freedom and independence.''

headline.main: Israel and Palestine, Side by Side?

docs.abstract: Letter from Shari G Mendes says Palestinian intellecturals who take out ads saying suicide bombings are not effective would do better to debate morality of those bombings, not their relative effectiveness (June 20 editorial)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    You note (editorial, June 20) that 55 Palestinian intellectuals took out an advertisement expressing their belief that suicide bombings ''do not achieve progress toward achieving our . . . freedom and independence.''

docs.lead_paragraph: In greater numbers than ever, China's villagers are using inexpensive prenatal scans and then abortion to prevent the birth of unwanted daughters and to ensure that they will bear a son, recent studies and census data show. Through the last decade, a time of rapid economic growth, the gap between male and female births only widened, giving China the largest gender disparity among newborns of any country in the world. In pockets of the countryside the imbalance is staggering, with births of as many as 144 boys recorded for every 100 girls.

headline.main: Desire for Sons Drives Use of Prenatal Scans in China

docs.abstract: China's villagers are using inexpensive prenatal scans and then abortion in greater numbers than ever to prevent birth of unwanted daughters and ensure they will have sons; recent studies and census data show gap between male and female births has only widened in last decade, giving China largest gender disparity in world; imbalance in some rural areas is staggering 144 boys for every 100 girls born; China's overall figure is 117 to 100, compared with 105 to 100 in US; photo; map; graph; example is southeastern region of Chaoyang, where daughters move away to husband's families, government no longer provides even pretense of old-age or medical care, and people depend on sons (M)
docs.snippet: In greater numbers than ever, China's villagers are using inexpensive prenatal scans and then abortion to prevent the birth of unwanted daughters and to ensure that they will bear a son, recent studies and census data show.    Through the last...

docs.lead_paragraph: Truth in Acting No one said, ''Here's to you, KATHLEEN TURNER,'' before she blew out the candles at a surprise party an hour after her final-scene towel drop in ''The Graduate.'' (It took a couple of tries. Three candles were stubborn. And, by the way, she is now 48.)

docs.lead_paragraph: With both Republicans and Democrats in Congress urging him to increase spending to fight global AIDS, President Bush announced a $500 million plan today to prevent expectant mothers from passing the AIDS virus to their babies. More than 2,000 infants are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus every day during pregnancy, birth or breast feeding, despite the widespread availability of cheap antiretroviral medicines that greatly reduce transmission of the virus from mother to child.

headline.main: Bush Offers Plan to Help Mothers Avoid Passing H.I.V. to Babies

docs.abstract: Pres Bush announces $500 million plan to prevent pregnant women from passing AIDS virus to their babies and reduce number of infected babies by 40 percent in dozen African nations and Caribbean; new money, which includes $200 million already set aside by Congress, will provide treatment to million women a year over five years; reaction among advocates for people with AIDS is mixed, with some praising Bush and others holding plan falls short of global needs (M)
docs.snippet: With both Republicans and Democrats in Congress urging him to increase spending to fight global AIDS, President Bush announced a $500 million plan today to prevent expectant mothers from passing the AIDS virus to their babies.    More than 2,000...

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a study that found most antiretroviral drugs safe for pregnant women infected with the AIDS virus referred incorrectly to the drug Sustiva, which one doctor said she avoided prescribing because it is known to cause birth defects in animals. Sustiva is an antiretroviral drug, but not in the protease inhibitor class, a class the study tentatively associated with low birth weight.
docs.abstract: Correction of June 13 article on study that found most antiretroviral drugs safe for pregnant women infected with AIDS virus
docs.snippet: An article on Thursday about a study that found most antiretroviral drugs safe for pregnant women infected with the AIDS virus referred incorrectly to the drug Sustiva, which one doctor said she avoided prescribing because it is known to cause birth...

docs.lead_paragraph: A utilityman for the Orioles, Melvin Mora changes positions as often as he changes his children's diapers. Being versatile is perhaps his biggest strength, and it is a good thing he has been so adaptable. Playing baseball nowadays is the easiest part of his life. Back home in Bel Air, Md., Melvin and his wife, Gisel, are busy rearing baby quintuplets and a 5-year-old girl.

headline.main: BackTalk; The Utilityman in the Nursery: Melvin Mora and His Quintuplets

docs.abstract: BackTalk column discusses other job of Baltimore Orioles utilityman Melvin Mora, whose role as father has stepped up since wife Gisel gave birth to quintuplets; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A utilityman for the Orioles, Melvin Mora changes positions as often as he changes his children's diapers. Being versatile is perhaps his biggest strength, and it is a good thing he has been so adaptable.    Playing baseball nowadays is the easiest...

docs.lead_paragraph: We used to think that the male human being could reproduce almost indefinitely. Look at George Plimpton, now 75 and the father of 7-year-old twins, and at the durable Saul Bellow, who at 84 became a father for the fourth time, with his fifth wife. And then there are those puzzling guys who often turn up on Madison Avenue on weekends -- the ones with the Barbour jackets and the sleek but gray $300 haircuts, and with very young children in tow. They could be grandpops, but in that neighborhood, chances are they're dads working on their second families, maybe even their third. In theory, they could have children younger than their grandchildren. Recently, though, some scientific evidence has come to light suggesting that male fertility may not be as ageless as we thought. The quality of a man's sperm may not deteriorate over time in quite the same way as the viability of a woman's eggs, but nevertheless something seems to happen, so that, all other things being equal, a man in his late 30's, say, is apt to have a harder time conceiving a child than a man 10 years younger. What this means is that buried deep in the Y chromosome, there may be the same inexorable timepiece that has lately been the source of so much anxiety among women -- the dread biological clock. The male version just ticks more slowly and with less urgency, and of course, nobody pays attention to it anyway.
docs.abstract: The Way We Live Now column by Charles McGrath on recent scientific evidence that male fertility, like female fertility, may not be as ageless as was thought; says in this age of cloning and reproductive miracles, even male sperm seems marginal contribution
docs.snippet: We used to think that the male human being could reproduce almost indefinitely. Look at George Plimpton, now 75 and the father of 7-year-old twins, and at the durable Saul Bellow, who at 84 became a father for the fourth time, with his fifth wife....

docs.lead_paragraph: Outside Phnom Penh, along a road running west to Cambodia's more rural provinces, sits an orphanage. It was built on a defunct rice paddy and caters exclusively to Americans wishing to adopt children. To get there, would-be parents travel from the city in air-conditioned cars with hired Cambodian drivers, passing windowless garment factories and the shanty settlements that have grown up to house thousands of workers. They pass legless land-mine victims begging money and old women wheeling carts of coconuts in the stultifying sun. Finally, they turn down a narrow washboard lane, which runs through a village and past a small Buddhist wat, or temple. Occasionally, the rice farmers look up from their work to watch the cars as they rise like apparitions from the dust -- white faces peering expectantly from the back seats -- and then disappear again, headed toward the orphanage. The moment is one of mutual disorientation.
docs.abstract: American parents adopting Cambodian children have reason to wonder if babies were bought or coerced from their mothers; few can know for sure because corrupt system erases baby's past; 16 orphanages that work with American adoption agencies have become focus of United States investigation of adoption practices in Cambodia, questioning whether adoption there has morphed from altruistic pursuit into highly lucrative industry; on Dec 21, Immigration and Naturalization Service Comr James Ziglar formally suspended new visa processing for adopted children in Cambodia, citing suspicions that they were being bought or stolen from their parents and put into orphanages with false paperwork to feed growing American demand for babies; Cambodian government, which began allowing foreign adoption in 1989, has done little to combat child trafficking; it is now cooperating with investigation; estimated 400 American families have been caught with adoptions in midprocess; photos (L)
